meanings.sent1: The teacher may preaccuse a student of cheating if they see suspicious behavior during the exam.
meanings.sent2: It is unfair to preaccuse someone of lying without any evidence.
meanings.sent3: Before the game even started, Tom decided to preaccuse his friend of cheating in the match.
meanings.sent4: The detective had a hunch and decided to preaccuse the suspect of the crime.

meanings.definition: To make an accusation before any proof is given.
meanings.sent1: The boss tends to preaccuse employees of mistakes without checking the facts first.
meanings.sent2: It is important not to preaccuse someone without solid evidence to support the claim.
meanings.sent3: Sarah liked to preaccuse her brother of eating her snacks, even though she had no proof.
meanings.sent4: The media often preaccuses individuals of wrongdoing before all the information is known.
meanings.sent5: The gossiping neighbor would preaccuse others of gossiping, creating a cycle of accusations.
